title: Arkiv Builder Track
description: Learn to build decentralized apps with Arkiv. Create entities, query data, and verify your work on-chain.

steps.title: Welcome to Arkiv
steps.description: Understand what Arkiv is and why it matters for decentralized data.

conceptCard.title: Data ownership matters
conceptCard.body: Traditional apps store your data in company databases. If the company shuts down, your data is gone. Arkiv stores data on-chain, meaning you own it independently of any company.

steps.title: Fork and Clone the Starter
steps.description: Fork the arkiv-nextjs-starter repository and set up your local development environment.

steps.title: Configure Environment Variables
steps.description: Set up your environment variables and connect to Arkiv network.

steps.title: Run the App Locally
steps.description: Start the development server and verify everything works.

steps.title: Create Your First Entity
steps.description: Write your first piece of data to Arkiv and understand the entity structure.

steps.title: Verify on Explorer
steps.description: Learn to verify your data on the Arkiv Explorer.

conceptCard.title: Trustless verification
conceptCard.body: You don't need to trust our servers. Anyone can verify data on the blockchain explorer. This is what 'trustless' means - you can verify instead of trust.

steps.title: The Walkaway Test
steps.description: Experience data persistence: stop your server and verify your data still exists.

steps.title: Understanding Arkiv Concepts
steps.description: Deep dive into attributes, payloads, and indexer lag.

conceptCard.title: Indexer lag is normal
conceptCard.body: When you write data to Arkiv, it takes a few seconds for indexers to process it. This is called 'indexer lag'. Good apps handle this gracefully by showing 'pending' states.

steps.title: Customize Your App
steps.description: Modify the starter app to create your own entity types and functionality.

steps.title: Deploy to Vercel
steps.description: Deploy your serverless Arkiv app to production on Vercel.

steps.title: Next Steps
steps.description: Explore advanced patterns and continue your Arkiv journey.

steps.title: Knowledge Check
steps.description: Test your understanding of Arkiv fundamentals.

questions.question: What happens to your data when a traditional web app shuts down?
options: The data is usually lost or inaccessible
questions.correctAnswer: The data is usually lost or inaccessible
questions.explanation: Traditional apps store data in company databases. When the company shuts down, that data is typically lost or becomes inaccessible.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Arkiv Explorer?
options: To verify data on-chain without trusting servers
questions.correctAnswer: To verify data on-chain without trusting servers
questions.explanation: The Explorer lets you independently verify that data exists on-chain, without trusting any server.

questions.question: Indexer lag means your transaction failed.
questions.explanation: Indexer lag is normal and expected. It just means the indexers haven't processed your transaction yet - not that it failed.

questions.question: Which fields should be stored in entity attributes vs payload?
options: Queryable fields in attributes, content in payload
questions.correctAnswer: Queryable fields in attributes, content in payload
questions.explanation: Attributes are indexed and queryable. Payload is for larger content that doesn't need to be searched.

questions.question: What is the 'walkaway test'?
options: Testing if the app works on mobile
Verifying data persists after shutting down your server
questions.correctAnswer: Verifying data persists after shutting down your server
questions.explanation: The walkaway test proves that your data exists independently of your server - a key property of decentralized data.

badge.name: Arkiv Builder
badge.description: Completed the Arkiv Builder track and demonstrated proficiency with decentralized data.
